It starts with a medley of Middle Eastern spices, which includes the strong labdanum/cistus smell, which has mysteriously been left off the list of fragrance notes above but is the strongest thing in this; it then moves to the amber and resins, mixed with a decided whiff of patchouli, which becomes very pronounced.

Ambers are usually nice by my lights, but the medicinal smell of the herbs and the strong whiff of patchouli made this particular one seem like a very expensive hippie fragrance: it seems like a much fancier version of what I often smell here in Portland on the light rail system. Unfortunately I thus associate these particular smells with someone trying (usually ineffectively) to mask their body odor, so I just could never enjoy this--in fact, I had a hard time thinking who would, given its cost; although I do appreciate how nicely it was put together.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Ambre sultan mi piace perchè evoca l'oscurità,come un fuoco che arde nel buio,calmo,misterioso,le erbe aromatiche conferiscono un tocco amarognolo e di contrasto .
E' molto caldo come profumo,vellutato,quasi appiccicoso,molto misterioso,denso, profondo.
Non è un profumo semplice ma dà molte soddisfazioni,è caldo e avvolgente,ricco,lussuoso,fatto con arte e consapevolezza e poi è profondo e magnetico.
Il calore dell'ambra esotica e solare.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Le Lion de Chanel reminded me of something, and now I realized what it was. To me, parts of it is pretty darn similar to Ambre Sultan!

This is a deceivingly simple, but oh so effective fragrance. To quote Lutens: "The point of departure was a scented wax, found in a souk and long forgotten in a wooden box. The amber only became sultanesque after I reworked the composition using cistus, an herb that sticks to the fingers like tar, then added an overtone that nobody had ever dreamed of: vanilla." This sentence, while definitely describing the scent accurately, amused me a little. Which perfumer has NOT considered a tone of vanilla added to amber?

With that said, this has a lot of beautiful smoky labdanum that is so much more interesting than most ambers due to the addition of cistus (which is taken from the leaves of the same plant you get labdanum from, the European Rock Rose) which gives it a herbal, spicy, and almost sweaty feel.

To me this is one of the best ambers around, and it strays from being another boring sweet one-dimensional amber with the help of the interesting facets of the cistus. Definitely recommended for a cozy and solemn cloud around you on cold days.

Notes: amber, cistus, vanilla

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I get oregano and clove In the opening which to me makes this medicinal mixed with cooking spices. This dries down to an amber sweetness along with a herbal spiciness kick. Not long lasting but you do get several hours of this interesting mixture. Not off putting just different.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: At the opening, it smells like a basic female perfume, but it does dry down to be something completely different! Sweet but spicy, rich and heavy but not overwhelming nor heady. If you like spicy/amber, this one is some signature scent material IMO.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I thought I'd love this, because every perfume I've ever loved has had amber in it. But this smelled so distinctly like a grandmother that I couldn't get past it. I think I like amber base notes only, I now understand. Oh well.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Today, I was invited for optional laurels, and thought of the bay leaves in this classic.
Ambre Sultan has been with me since its inception, and -as an amber lover- I can hardly recommend any amber more sophisticated, elegant, and worth your money.
This is so beautiful, rich, understated, classy.

I could go on, but this does not need elaborate laurels. It speaks for itself.
A perfect unisex brew. Love!

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Bring the old bottle back, its was more chic, this one looks so cheap

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I had so much hope for this one. A bit disappointed after trying it. I was expecting something like Mfk grand soir but all i can smell is just a bunch of eastern spices. Yes the name speaks for itself Ambre Sultan, so eastern and so exotic. Reminds me a lot of hot Indian markets 😃

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Interesting scent profile. Like a strong medicinal and herbaceous amber. For exactly 20 minutes, then dissipates into a skin scent for the remainder of 40 minutes and then absolutely nothing. My skin hates longevity but this is a new low for SL. Profoundly disappointed with the purchase, but I'll keep it around for the weird comfort it provides.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I've just tried this today. It is much more subtle than I was expecting after the initial application which was very amber forward. It mellowed out incredibly quickly into a sort of warm and spicy herbaceous mix that I like. It reminds me of Jaipur Homme, which my dad wears. It's sort of like a mug of spiked cider not in scent but in vibe.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
My signature!

It has been love at first sniff, a moment of epiphany - this is when I finally understood what I was looking for in terms of perfume and why lots of other perfumes won't do. Other perfumes are my dessert, my snack, my appetizer... this is my main course.

Deep, dark, gorgeous. It's THE amber. Spicy, balsamic, not aggressively herbal, and so luxurious. This is luxe in a bottle for me. A waterfall of luscious amber. Projection, sillage and lasting power are solid.
I'm in love.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: fire in a bottle ! the experience I felt for this scent was like drinking whisky for the first time.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
If many of the early Serge Lutens perfumes do not seem unique it is because they have been prolifically copied. They are a house that anyone interested in perfume history or wanting to develop their nose should explore. Ambre Sultan in particular seems to have inspired many perfumes.

Ambre Sultan is a classic amber with a heavy dose of labdanum and exotic herbs and spices. Its directness and lack sweetness make it lean masculine to my nose. It is bold with good longevity and projection.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Okay, so I blind bought this after consulting with a friend about my likes and dislikes.
Upon first smell, it’s like walking into an empty Catholic church (or anywhere that is heavy on incense). I find it really savoury - there’s little to no sweetness at all but it feels like a rich, warm hug in those kind of shops that sell witch/pagan gifts. Bizarrely, as I’m typing I get a distinct smell of the sour fizzy cola bottles, but it remains spicy. Not what I imagined but nice nonetheless. I’ll update this at a later date with how it wears.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: The best amber perfume.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I never blind-bought any perfume before, so all the ones in my collection are perfumes that I adore and reach for. The amount of love this perfume gets is insane till the point I had to blind-buy it and I'm glad I did. It is heavy on frankincense, myrrh, and amber. I will say that if you like Grand Soir by MFK, you're going to LOVE this perfume. To me these two perfumes sit on the throne of amber perfumes in terms of scent.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: What can I say that hasn't already been said? I'll just add that this is the best amber I have ever smelled in my life. I have tried others but they all pale in comparison. I think SL is an absolute master and I really appreciate his take on perfume. Ambre Sultan is everything I ever dreamed of in an amber. It is so rich and sexy and I just want to eat it up. I'm a woman and I wear it proudly and honestly I have no idea why people find it masculine. I find it perfectly unisex and perfectly wearable by anyone with a little confidence and sex appeal. I love the sweetness and the spice and the richness of it, so I think it's really perfect for a cozy winter scent (although I would proudly wear it year round) :)

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
This to me will always be the paragon of ambers.

In 2008, I wandered into Barney's in Copley Square Boston and discovered the wide world of high-end and niche fragrance (before I believe "niche" was even really a descriptor) and was struck by their Serge Lutens counter and its display of understated, elegant and somewhat austere bottles. I was really immediately drawn in by the dense and complex scents, otherworldly and enchanting to me at the time. The saleswoman offered me samples of three: Chergui, Arabie, and Ambre Sultan. I was smitten with all three and went on my way, using these small atomizers sparingly so as to relish them. Shortly thereafter, I flirted with fragrance buying, having purchased a handful of others in the next year or two (a couple of which were somewhat regrettable decisions in retrospect: Bond No. 9 Coney Island, yikes). However, curiously enough, I never bought a full bottle of any Serge Lutens. My collection only grew to about may 10 or so bottles at one point and I then started to direct my attention elsewhere.

Fast forward about seven years later, and the art of perfume making caught my attention after purchasing a few bottles of essential oil to diffuse. I continued pretty consistently but have never taken to another level, due to fear and anxiety of the sheer dedication and amount of money that must be invested to start a fragrance line and a small business in general (I am feeling more and more confident as of late, stay tuned). This has led, however, to much deeper appreciation for fragrance and scent, studying hundreds of natural materials and aromachems, learning from mentors in the fragrance community, collecting and educating myself through fragrance composition books, studying the history of perfume, and then came 2020.

2020, the year of horror, disbelief, anger, tragedy, and sadness in multitudes: I will leave it at that. What would preoccupy me during all this difficult stuff? Somehow, 2020 was also the year that out of nowhere, I decided, why not buy a few full bottles of some fragrances that I love and appreciate (a few he says, a FEW). I caught the full bottle bug, as it were, and I am just now trying to reign it in—and it hasn't even been a full calendar year!

I finally purchased bottles of Chergui, Arabie, and Ambre Sultan, twelve or so years later (and I didn't stop there as far as Serge Lutens is concerned, no doubt). So I sit here, with it sprayed on the interior on my forearm, and I periodically sniff through each stage of its development and big love is still there. That opening is rapturous bliss, warm, sweet and resinous, then in the dry down, the oregano, bay leaf, angelica, and myrtle, these are what sing on my skin in the most wonderfully peculiar manner; ahhhh...this is what got me hooked, this left field of herbal melange with animalic undertones. Then it dries in time to a dry myrrh and somber, dusty labdanum, with an outline of benzoin and vanilla; mythical, even transcendental to my nose.

What I've learned in my full bottle journey this year is sometimes you go back "home" to what initiated that spark, what ignites that passion, drives one's desire and is a reminder of what is essential, These are indulgences of what are sensory and sensual, after all. Will I continue to acquire more? Yes, but one most slow down and eventually stop somewhere—it has already surpassed what could be considered practical or even dare I say healthy (I've been a voracious collector at heart since I was single-digit aged). I do think, however, that if I had to stop here, I'd be happy that I finally have a bottle of my Ambre Sultan.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Everything is already said:
Heavy on amber, reisins and myrrh. Backed up by patchouli for the skanky vibe. (But not too skanky.)
I´ve tried so many amberfrags.
This is the only one i really need. (And Zegnas Passion....please check that one out...)
Ambre Sultan is sexy and lasts a long time on skin.
What could you possible ask for more?
Just buy it.

Instagram: @a_fraghags_tale

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Quite well named. Pretty Middle Eastern to my nose, so it's not for me. You're hit with a blast of pungent green spices over a sweet, heavy amber base. Leans masculine, and becomes sweeter rather than the initial spicy pretty quickly into the dry down.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Too savory for me i'm picking up all the herbal and green notes the corriander, bay, and oregano especially are all coming out to me. Even in the dry down it's not so amber to me, more of an amalgam of spices i would like to cook with.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: On my skin this opened up very strongly with the bay leaf and it never left. It kind of ruined the rich impression of the amber scent for me, it felt like I couldn’t quite get to the good part for most of the wearing. I have cooler temp skin and I’m female so perhaps that skin chemistry just ended up turning this more herbal than resinous. As it dried down the bay leaf did settle out and balance with the rest of the notes more but I just found it to be slightly too masculine for my taste.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I want this perfume to tie me down and do unspeakable things to me. I want it to spank me and make me call it daddy. Whoosh. On first test I smell warm amber and resin and spice...excellent so far. I worked out in it...still smells good, maybe even a bit better because my skin is heated up. Put another dab on after a hot shower and wow does hot skin bring out more of the notes. Right now it is amber, spice, hint of myrrh, and possibly the bay leaf everyone refers to...it isn't an obvious herbal smell, but it's a hint of something different than the rest of the warm notes...gives it a bit of something undefinable, maybe strikes just the right hint of balance to keep the amber and resin from being too sweet.
I have hope that this frag is going to wear me out all day. I'll check back in with longevity. If Arabie was love (it was and is), then Ambre Sultan is unbridled lust.
UPDATE: After about 6 hours it becomes a skin scent, still gorgeous, a lovely afterglow. At 14 hours it is barely discernible, but I can still catch faint whiffs of beautiful warm sweetness if I put my nose to my skin.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I blind bought Amber Sultan from online store after the hype from YouTube reviewers, and the fact I own Santal Majuscule and I really love it (simple, reach, creamy and rosy sandalwood).

When I received it, it reminded me immediately of Bentley for man intense, but less sweet and without the boozy vibe.

"Main Accords" bars (on top right of the page) describes it very well, much better than the note voting.

It is way more resinous than ambery, it goes ambery but never make it, it's even aromatic more than ambery, and it can easily be cloying in warmer weather, it lacks some sweetness to match the warmth of the dense resinous smell.

That's being said, I still like it, but it's not what I expected.
If you like sweet, simple amber this might not be your favorite.

I would give it 7/10, and I don't think I'll buy it again.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: @ maruistao not a chance similar to Journey!!! This is a beautiful full spiced Amber...

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I loooove a good amber. This one is super duper on point. It’s almost boring to review it, because it’s so well done. Like, what do you say? Yeah, it’s perfect.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Smelled this for the first time ever in a store, beautiful fragrance! Got the paper strip home. Both opening and dry down remind me quite a bit of Bentley for Men Intense, which I also find fascinating and beautiful on its own.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Just an absolutely warm, comforting, exotic scent. It is a staple of my collection and I never want to be without it, especially in the fall and winter. That said, I live in a tropical climate, and it works just fine in the heat and humidity, as long as I go light on the application. The oregano and bay are dominant in the open, but after maybe 30 minutes a spicy incense accord opens up and takes over. After about another 30 minutes, a warm, slightly honeyed amber accord emerges with vanilla undertones. This scent envelops me for about 7 hours. Both projection and sillage are moderate. I would love to get my hands on a vintage bottle to compare performance. That said, I am perfectly happy with the current formulation and think it is a great value at the price.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I got several samples to get my nose on and one was an Amber fragrance. At first it didn’t really live up to all the hype that I had seen but I wore it a few more times and then I understood all the positive reviews thus falling in love with the note of amber. I then started seeking the best amber fragrance and Serge Lutens Ambre Sultan kept surfacing. It got my attention and I blind bought this. At work I received a notice that it was delivered waiting for me once I got home. For once I was excited and couldn’t wait to get home. Once unpacking I unscrew the top and let me say, in all honesty, it was love at first sniff! POW; one of those WOW fragrances. I’ll admit this is my first amber fragrance but not certain I’ll seek any more with having this. One thing for certain; it will always be a bottle of this within reach from here on out! Instantly one of my top 5 fragrances. Warm, smooth, spicy , slightly sweet, that projects a good 6 feet and performs on my skin 8-10 hrs. I woke up the following morning and could still smell it on my wrist. If you are straddling the fence about this one, I highly recommend you quit putting it off. My sample was TF’s Amber Absolu and to me this is every bit as good for a fraction of the cost and easy to get!

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Heavenly amber. Warm, exotic, mysterious and a bit spicy. Just like a good lover. 😉

The amber is a dry and dusty powdery vanilla, which combines with the resins and spices to resemble a hot desert air blowing over a Moroccan market.

I think I love it but the special blend of herbs and spices make it smell too much like food for my liking. Less the mysterious, handsome stranger I wanted to be and more like a casserole/tagine. The performance is slightly poor as well. Big tick for Tom Ford's AA.

Edit: just reworn TF-AA: I miss the herbs. One-all. The bay-leaf in Amber Sultan does give it a little more balance and (in a way) mystery, and as such is slightly more rewarding. Amber Absolute relies solely on the resins.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I'll agree with what others have said here: this is the Holy Grail of amber fragrances.

It's dense but never stifling, sweet but never cloying (thanks to the oregano and angelica), and has an animalic, furry, purring heart.

I also agree with the general consensus that this is an adult fragrance — elegant and very posh.

I see most people have classified this as a fall/winter scent. It's the middle of July here in the US, 90ºF and fairly humid, and I have to say, this blooms beautifully in the heat albeit with significantly fewer sprays than I'd use in cooler weather.

This is an incredible perfume and I hope I never have to be without it at any point in the future.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
oh wow not what I was expecting. this stuff is extremely manly. not for the feint of heart. this wouldn't be good for anyone under age 35-40. this is a man's man cologne. it reminds me of bentley intense. it's not very ambery to my nose, at least that's my first impression. more like boozy cigar smell with a touch of sweet

second impression- same thing! just smells boozy and tobacco. just like a toned down version of bentley intense. no detectable amber whatsoever. it's a weaker, higher quality version of bentley intense with a touch more balsamic notes. and that's it haha

it smells good. better than bentley intense. but the performance is sub par so I can't recommend it. if it performed and the price was better I'd say get this over bentley intense

third impression- after the dry down this changes into something darker than bentley intense. similar to Armani code absolu although less sweet. but it's in that vein. I do finally pick up a little bit of amber, however it's so hard to tell that it's amber because of how dark and boozy this fragrance is. the performance is still sub par, but not quite as weak as I first thought. projection is minimal but sillage is pretty decent. all in all this is a quality frag like all serge lutens, but it's not groundbreaking in uniqueness as it smells like a lot of other fragrances on the market

overall this is not a sweet crowd pleasing amber fragrance. this is a dark, boozy, balsalmic offering that is for formal wear only. this is polarizing as it's very dark and brisk, just like bentley intense. it is a mix between that and Armani code profumo. so if you own those fragrances you won't need this at all. this is for a man if anyone is wondering. a formal dressed man at say a cocktail lounge or a singles party for well dressed high to do people.

scent-6.5/10
value-3/10
uniqueness-4/10
performance-5/10
overall-6/10

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
This. Is. A. Piece. Of. Art.

Pure amber and churchy myrrh mixed with vivacious herbs like thyme, rosemary and menthol. This is masculine, sexy, dark and mysterious. This is what you pair with a brown peacoat in the cold days, having people looking back at you whilst you make an impact. I am too young to wear this but it is a a masterpiece from SL. The herbs are so realistic in this you can even taste them, that menthol medicinal note is strong and intertwines with the amber perfectly. For 30+, cold to cool nights, best for a date, bar, chill night with friends.

For me 10/10

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
This is excellent. You can really detect all the various spicy nuances. There’s a lot going on here. It’s not a projector but has very good longevity.
9/10

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: It is 72 degrees currently and I think I like it better in heated seasons than in the cold seasons... I feel like I’m covered by a Saharan Air. I guess it appeals either way but it hits different in Warmer seasons seemingly.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
The bay leaf note intrigued me before testing, but now I can say that it is its main downfall, for me. It gives it a noticeably herbal touch which makes it feel quite dated and stuffy. AS goes the resinous route with its amber and leaves out any real sweetness. Spices lay in the background, drying everything out.

In a saturated amber market there are much better options out there for my tastes.

Indifferent

(dislike/indifferent/like, but not BW/like, potentially BW/love, definitely BW/masterpiece)

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Whoa!! I love this. Something slightly medicinal about it but it fades after a few minutes and warms your soul. It reminds me of Cartier's La baiser du dragon, then I checked the notes and they are about the same. Cartier is louder to me but Serge Lutens is warmer and not too too mature like Cartier Baiser du dragon.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
The opening of this was really dirty, almost to the point where I didn't like it but that quickly faded. What was left was a wonderful warm and cosy amber. It's spicy, resinous and perfect for cool weather. A real comfort scent.

It's incredibly similar to Tom Ford's Amber Absolute, which I already own so it seems pointless purchasing this too, however I feel that this one is less cloying and slightly less sweet than AA, making it easier to wear and probably more of a crowd pleaser.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Lovely amber fragrance. Dries own to a slightly animalic spicy smell, a bit like a cat's fur. Curiously similar after dry down to chergui.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I now own this and Chergui from Serge Lutens (which I absolutely love), this one is definitely a masterpiece, i cant stop wearing it for three days in a row now... beautiful powdery and cozy smell that lasts all day without biting your nose off, i definitely recommend this.

As always i was testing another fragrance on my other arm and on a side note: pdm herod and this get along very well ;)

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: A masterpiece....period.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Don’t understand how anyone can dislike this. I almost scored a vintage bottle on Ebay but I was outbid at the last moment- wasn’t paying attention! Anyway I love the current formulation just fine- I didn’t get to smell the old one. I’m not overwhelmed by bay leaf. What I experienced is a warm composition. I’m bummed I lost- might have to get a new one on Ebay. Can’t believe how great Ebay is for frags.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: i smell resins, specifically labdanum. also myrrh, benzoin and bay leaf. after a few more minutes i get a larger dose of amber but there are still herbs present, though i'd say it's mostly amber and resins. it smells similar to other resiny-amber scents i've tried but the addition of the herbs is unique-it gives it a dry quality and it's a little more grounded due to the herbal element.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
This is a good example of what could've been a perfect fragrance, but has been significantly compromised to appeal to a mainstream audience.

the good: wow, this is lush, complex, embracing and beautiful. branches of herbs are draped over a gorgeous ambery heart, clouds of edible sweetness envelop its wearer.

the bad: way too much sweetness. cloying, thick, imbalanced. this is a good example of niche, but engineered to be a western crowd pleaser (EG sugar in every processed thing we eat).

imagine a hybrid of jabba the hutt and the marshmallow man, in a herbal ghillie suit.

this should've been a fine wine, or whisky. instead, it is vanilla coca-cola.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Ambre Sultan by Serge Lutens is essentially a classic amber enriched with powdery and vanilla notes coming from the resins of small Siam trees which produce benzoin. These natural resins are mixed with labdanum, with coriander, oregano, bay leaves, myrtle, the whole is subtly rounded thanks to angelica roots, sandalwood and patchouli leaves. Cozy, unique, this beautiful fragrance became a real classic of niche modern perfumery. It is a classic amber enriched with natural resins. Irresistible and addictive...

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Maybe it’s the name, but I have visions of a tent camp in the desert with a central “living, dining” tent with lively carpets on the sand and lounging chairs holding plump cushions. I spent a long weekend at such a camp south of Algiers 24 years ago. If I had been wearing this perfume, it would have made an already exotic adventure even more so. I have to keep sniffing the top of my wrist (my favorite place to sniff frequently) to follow its evolution. At first, it faintly reminded me of those Christmas incense cones we used to burn in my childhood, woodsy and spices. Now it’s soft, gentler, but still basically the same. It doesn’t shout, so I can see wearing it anywhere and not overpowering a room. This version is the EDP I got in a 3 ml decant, obviously not enough now. Someone said “honey”. Yes, I perceive a bit, but not very sweet. It’s mostly spicy and calls for a fireplace to be lit and a hot toddy maybe?

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
This is for batch code YGG54X. The maker is shiseido sa.

Anyway, it's the brown liquid bottle, very nice fragrance. When first applied, I get an overwhelming Amber, vanilla, honeyed coriander scent. Maybe some bay leaf and myrrh. Definitely has the resins going on mixed with the benzion.

It's soft, beautiful, meant to be enjoyed more at night by a fire with a special someone. It's a very special scent for close love encounters.

Starts out powerful and morphs into a much warmer fragrance at the 3rd hour. It's got good longevity, I'd say 7 hours at least. Projection is moderate overall. I don't know if what I have is vintage, but I'd say it's two to three years old. In any case, I wear very seldomly and it's best fitted for cooler climates. Very beautiful Amber and well suited for close encounters!

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
A very herbal amber, very contrasting notes it makes this fragrance more interesting. It's not for me but very nice.
★★★☆☆

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Just sampling this. It is very similar to Ambre Aurea by Profumum Roma but just a little less of the spice. I own the latter so would not want both but can't go wrong with either.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I got this yesterday. I loved the opening blast but felt it became a bit too tame, too quickly. After another day of wearing it though, I have changed my mind. This is just such an incredibly charming fragrance,just so damn pleasant to wear. It really envelopes the wearer in a cloak of warmth. I wish the herbal notes hung around a little bit longer, and it doesn't seem to have great sillage (though longevity is decent), but I find myself sniffing my wrists constantly while wearing it, it is so comforting, soothing, calming. The overall effect is akin to getting an aromatherapy massage with a base of beeswax and coconut oil on a private island. This smells like money and sunshine, I feel like a king, a very chilled out king, when wearing this. Santal Majuscule remains my favourite Lutens so far (and I've only tried a few), but this comes a close second. I bought 100ml on a blind buy, absolutely no regrets. Anyone who likes this would probably also like Tom Ford Tobacco Vanille, that one has a similar warmth, but on my skin at least, retains its herbal qualities a bit longer. Lutens is really a force to be reckoned with, such interesting and evocative fragrances.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Old books, dust, and wood. What I would smell while rifling through antiques. Or 19th century houses with staircases made of mahogany. Also sense clay/dirt and wood polish. I'm liking it the more I smell it. I think it just takes some time for the nose to adjust; a challenging scent.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
This is a very high quality Amber fragrance that sticks around for a good 12 hours without being too strong. I have the newer reformulated version which I believe is weaker than the original formulation. The Amber is quiet linear & I would say that it is a more date night fragrance. Good for all seasons.
If you are an Amber fragrance lover, then you must have this in your collection.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
اغواگر و شهوانی کاملا یونی

Seductive & sensual -unisex

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
YES SENSUAL
اغواگر و سنشوال

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Ambre Sultan is the masterpiece of the top of mind in a world perfumery. I lovely this fragrance, the honey are sweet and the tobacco are dirty, but, don´t that dirty with the sky, it is dirty same well.
I have a cousin that costume used Ambre Sultan for take a got a Gym. He is make lot of milk, but the smell don´t influenced in your decisions.
Ambre Sultan opening a floral juice and lost in a mix of roses and gardens in a military reserve.
I like Ambre Sultan, but don´t love, i loved more than the heart closed more pineapple and tuberose.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
It begins with a tango between kitchen herbs (a black-pepepry spicy bay leafs mostly) and perhaps dry labdanum.

Then (maybe) the labdanum turns to its balsamic sour side, even with a barely recognizable rhubarb hint: my guess is, this is due to the muffled plastic incense at the bottom.

Next, the big chunk of body note —— (maybe) myrrh —— steps up. It smells like a mellow, tuber-y traditional Chinese herb (板蓝根), with a dash of bitter juice. I also sensed the muffled plastic incense hint.

Before you know it, a...what can I say...clotted creamy waxy note, with the faintest petroleum hint, crept beneath the myrrh. Is that Benzoin, or just another facet of myrrh?

At the far end of dry down, after it turns into a skin scent, the bitter juice aspect of Myrrh(?) becomes more prominent, still mixed with a few kitchen herbs, along with a date pit-like labdanum.

I don't really know why this is called Ambre Sultan. A Kitchen in Harem is a better name.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Serge Lutens brand is for me ruled by Amber Sultan. Beautiful resineous sweet and spicy scent. I love to wear it for special occasions. It is very original, confident and sophisticated fragrance that shouts class an refinement miles around you.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Notes to my nose Coriander, Bay Leaf, Patchouli, Resins, Sandalwood, Amber and Vanilla

Smoky Resins combined with spices make this a magical scent. If you love Amber like i do, you will definitely love this one but Amber Absolute by Tom Ford is still my favorite.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
All i get are some spices + unpleasant sweetness.
I tried several times to wear it and to like it, but this is not what i expected to be.
I work with amber and sand it, i know its resinous, woodsy smells of pine and amber sultan is not this kind of smell, because the spices here are too loud.
Very disappointed.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Basic oud and amber scent!!

The opening is very stinky, animalic, woodsy, super spicy, and dry amber; I would say it gives an Arabian-middle eastern vibe!; in the dry-down it does sweeten-up slightly, the ingredients pop out clearly, the resins show up, more types of woods, and of course all in the presence of The King "Amber".
perfect for the winter, unisex tends to be more masculine.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
In the opening i get a very spicy smell, but it is sweet and somehow juicy. It makes me think of some kind of red sweet spicy soft drink, it is very strong in the opening

As it starts to dry down it reminds me of Chergui and becomes more honey like. the overall scent is very warming and i love that opening.

The performance on my skin is very good with excellent projection.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
A strong like/love from me for this.
Woody, ambery, and spicy.
Reminds me of Ormonde Jayne Ormonde Man a little.
I only have a 10ml decant at the moment, but will invest in a full bottle in the future.
Quite a safe buy in my opinion. I find nothing challenging in it myself, but it may just be my type of thing.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
This was a surprise. Didn't smell anything like I imagined.

I just sprayed this on about thirty minutes ago. It goes on dry, and scratchy. Almost like splintering wood. But when it mellows down, on my skin, the resins and amber have been producing a honey-like sweetness. It's VERY sweet.

The bay leaf and coriander however, give it a really strong, peppery note that strangely compliments the smooth sweetness of the resins well, and gives it a dry smoke quality, while also being oily.

I initially thought I'd made a mistake with this, because bay leaf and coriander usually ruin perfumes for me. However, it's growing on me. I'll update at the end of the day to see how I feel about it overall.

UPDATE:

This rapidly grew on me. I really did not like it to begin with. I didn't like the intense sweetness of the resins paired with the herbal scent of the sage and coriander. However, the combination grew on me and I found myself wearing my sample to death because I liked it so much.

This does not have much projection. Maybe twelve inches off the skin, at most. So anyone very near you will smell it, but it won't fill a room by any means. I would say this has excellent lasting power, lasting eight hours on my skin. This is no small task, as my skin burns through perfumes like no other.

However, would I recommend this as a safe buy? Not in the slightest. Don't buy this on a whim. This will absolutely not please everyone. Were it solely a resin fragrance, it might be more crowd-pleasing, but the addition of sage is not a note everyone will enjoy. If you do decide to give it a chance, I'd recommend extended testing, because if it repulsed you as much as it did me at first, you may just need to sit with it for a while before you make your final decision.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
The perfect mix of amber and incense.

Dried fruits that come wrapped in a blanket of spicy yet creamy and warm, almost slightly burnt amber with sprinklings of oregano, coriander and bay leaf.

This is not as much a sweet amber as it is a dirty one - a great fusion of notes with the incensy amber playing the main theme. Very well composed, even if the notes are somewhat stereotypical, the art here is making them work together very seamlessly which Sheldrake manages to A+. After the first half hour it's pretty linear and not evolving that much, but it is long lasting, dry, rich and deep with some reminiscence of an arabian souq. I even find some tiny similarities to Tauer's LADDM, as it is only slightly - as in very little - sweeter. Also, what makes it stand out from other ambers, is the herbal aspect which keeps it from smelling too sweet and at the same time makes it continually interesting to return to.

If you're an amber lover you should definitely check this out, personally I find this one of the top 3 ambers I've ever tried.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I really enjoy the intial spray of this and about 10 mins into settling on my skin, but as it dries down I get a lot of sandalwood which I don't like, I much prefer ambre loup from rania J and profumum romas ambre aurea which are slightly thicker and sweeter-

7/10

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
The first few minutes, I get mint&rosemary. When the initial alcohol blast has evaporated, the bay leaf unveils its real face, dancing with a strong myrrh, and supported by vanilla and patchouli in the background. That's it for now, and so will it be for the rest of the show, as this perfume is very linear.

Amber has no smell in itself. What people usually call "amber" is simply vanilla, supported by resins (labdanum and/or myrrh and/or opoponax) and possibly sandalwood.
While I think this fragrance is well blended, and definitely has the Lutens signature, its name is misleading. This should have been named Bay Leaf Sultan.

The bay leaf may be hard to pull out for a man, and I would tend to see this one as more leaning towards feminine for that reason. Just my opinion.
A pass for me, but still a great and unique sweet bay leaf/myrrh fragrance, if that's what you're looking for.

Edit: I tried it again on skin several times after my review. I am still not sure what is the hype on this one. It's a good amber fragrance, but quite linear: starts bay leaf/myrrh/vanilla, and the only evolution is a change in roles, as it ends vanilla/myrrh/bay leaf. The myrrh is intoxicating, but I still don't fully enjoy the bay leaf (that said, it's an original combo) and the vanillic drydown is generic compared to other ambers.
It's good, and I understand some like it, but I really don't understand why this one is often cited in the top 3 of the best Lutens fragrances... maybe because it's simple and the vanilla makes it easy to wear....?
Final call: definitely deleted from my wishlist.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
REFORMULATION ALERT
Sad day. The new bottle with the ugly 80s type has been reformulated, and it’s linear and thin. It’s no longer the warm spice bomb of its former self. Why Serge, why? You messed with a classic amber scent and created a very BORING scent. I’m so upset.

On fragrancenet they are still showing the older packaging, but they sent the new label bottle. That’s not what I ordered so it’s going back, and I’ll be looking on eBay, I feel duped. Buyer beware.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Busy opening with lots of spices that are in front of a burning incense, but the amber stills the spotlight, no doubt. It's thick, dry, very spicy and resinous. As the scent develops, it gets sweeter and warmer, it loses the harshness of the avalanche of spice blend from the start and it gets better, in my opinion. But there are no real detours from the path, the stuff is pretty linear.
7.5/10

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
A stone classic: the very definition of what upscale dry amber should be. Strong and resinous but still sweet, welcoming and comfortable, with a spice blend of unique elegance and distinction. Absolutely unisex, but its avatars in my mind are Cary Grant, James Mason, George Clooney - old-world elegance, effortless charm and warmth that radiates from within. This one really opened my eyes to what an amber scent could be - not just vanilla sugariness and a generic vague cuddle, but a much more adult and sophisticated milieu which demands more of you. It's a strong - maybe breathtaking - embrace and a reassuring pat of encouragement on the back. Makes you want to be a better man (even if you're a lady - and I do encourage women to try this one out.) You could settle into this one like a robust, well-upholstered sofa and live there happily for ever after. Projection is in the just-right mid range and longevity's solid - 7h and beyond on my skin. Just stellar.

Having said that: I can't deal with the bayleaf over time (it gives me a headache...) so I must have a little solo weep about that and go with some other dry ambers that don't have Sultan's herbal edge. It is so nearly a lifetime love and I can absolutely recognise and back up its reputation as a champion in the field. But oh, that bullying bay ... begone, vexatious leaf! Otherwise pretty much perfect. For me, Ambre Sultan will be forever the Oh So Nearly scent, the one that got away.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I had a bottle many years ago with the Palais Royal label. It was a knockout. Yes there was sweet amber but it was intertwined with the most sophisticated mix of “herbal tobacco” (that’s what it smelled like to me) and gave off a sillage that smelled like old money. It was pure magic to top off your fall/winter wardrobe with a scent like that, people seemed to want to get closer and investigate. I got alot of compliments wearing it and one time a potential client asked in the middle of our meeting “what is that heavenly scent that you are wearing?” and not only did I book the job but years later she informed me that she bought a bottle for her husband and it is now his favorite. I like the memory of this because these people were nouveau riche and really needed some Lutens in their lives to complete the look of the roles they were trying to play. I don’t think she’d even ever heard of Serge Lutens. Anyways, when that bottle ran out I bought a new one from a discount fragrance site (new label, not the latest black one but the intermediate) and it was unmistakably duller, sweeter, and weaker in sillage. It was Ambre Sultan (same notes) but like a xerox copy with the machine running out of ink. I held onto it and planned to buy one direct from SL the next time I go to Paris to replace it. But when I went to Paris, I sampled Ambre Sultan in the shop and it was exactly like the new bottle I owned at home. Now I read reviews that confirm what I have experienced and it seems the original formula has been tweaked atleast enough to notice. It’s still wonderful and after selling my second bottle on ebay, I think that I will try and save up for a vintage bottle. Great stuff that really IMO deserves the hype. Amber is already a crowd pleaser but Serge Lutens and Christopher Sheldrake really are genius here when they contrasted its’ cozy sweet warmth with dry, herbal, piquant, smokey goodness. EDIT: I finally purchased a vintage bottle and I realize now that the difference between the old and new formulas isn’t as dramatic as I may have thought when I wrote the above. It comes down to the herbal notes being softer in the new formula and the sweetness more pronounced, less complex. It’s still a great perfume.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
So I was at a job interview at Barney's Department Store --Restaurant, Fred's, and just decided to at least give a visit to the perfume department and lucked up on a sample of Ambre Sultan.

I'm not a passionate fan of Serge Luten, for no reason at all. I love Tubereuse Criminelle a lot but I think the prices of this line just deter me. Reading the notes, I didn't think Ambre Sultan would really appeal to me or be as heavily aromatic.However, It does give off an expensive smoke smell, in a Shalimar like way --which I love. ( Go, Myrrh) I can't say I'm crazy about this, but it worth my attention and more appealing than Vanille Bois.

The sales associate were nice and generous as if she knew I wasn't going to get the job and that made the trip worth it, and now I want to return and get a full bottle of Ambre Sultan as that it price is not too threatening at 150.00. Though I'm not passionate about the line, I can not take away the strength/heaviness that are these fragrance --which holds my attention. I complain about the price but with the strength and heavy aroma of Serge Lutens --it worth it... and Ambre Sultan certainly is. ( oh, that Fille en Aiguilles-marvelous )

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: The latest version just reminds me of cream soda, which isn't a bad thing. I could wear this on occasion.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Scrumptious. That’s really the best way to describe it.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I love amber dominant scents. Favorites include Hermes’ Elixir des Merveilles, Ambre Fétiche from Annick Goutal, MFK’s Grand Soir and Ambre Extreme from L`Artisan Perfumer. Today I can add Ambre Sultan to that list.

It should come as no surprise that I’m also a Serge Luten fan, even when I find his creations difficult to wear I still respect the compositions. But that’s not Ambre Sultan. This dark beauty is easy to wear: smoky resins combined with spices take this scent in an erotic direction. Bay leaf makes an entrance after the initial 10 minute opening.

If there’s anything critical to point out it’s that this perfume is quite linear. That’s not an issue for me because I love it as is. Performance is very good, projection is moderate with just one spray.

If you love amber, this is a must try. Another piece of perfume art from the house of Serge Luten.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Expected more of resins, but all i get is some very sweet spices.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Unfortunately, it's another No for me from the Lutens offerings. Why? Because I waited almost eight hours to escape this aromatic print of the bay leaf and it does not happen ... even the last trace of the perfume on the skin is dominated by this facet. I am extremely sorry because I wanted to find here a warm, extravagant and exceptional amber.

I jumped over A.P Ambre Orient tester in dutyfree where I tested almost the whole line, but looking at the pyramid I think it's missing out what Ambre Sultan has in a great amount ... this aromatic character. So, it goes on the asap test list and it's not going to be missed next time!

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Un' ambra mai sentita prima, seducente, intrigante e sensuale. Un' ambra fusa con le resine, le spezie e la mirra.
Mi ricorda vagamente Gucci Absolute, Dior Fahrenheit e in alcuni momenti anche Encre Noir... ma è solo un attimo... qui sono su un altro pianeta. Ci sono tanti tipi di ambra e poi c'è lei...AMBRE SULTAN ... un caldo abbraccio-

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: One of the most seductive amber in contemporary perfumery. The Lutens house is sold everywhere now also in supermarkets, but this fragrance is part of the history of perfumes. Nice drydown towards a beach of Sardinia or Sicily through the Mediterranean scrub .. more than the far east.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
not strictly about this fragrance but an experience linked to Ambre Sultan. Revisiting a fragrance is always an interesting experience and was curious about this one...it's been 7-8 years since I first sniffed this, at the beginning of my fragrance journey; to put it nicely. Fragrance haze and obsession is probably more appropriate as to what was happening but I know that I am in safe hands here now, so I'm comfortable with my confession.
So..back to the fragrance. It is less sweet than I remembered and also more woody. Still liking it, that has not changed, so I guess Ambre Sultan is one of my timeless likes. Interestingly I seem to get 8 hrs out of this, not a massive silalge but wafts here and there..
Memories are fickle but it's true. Feelings awakened by a fragrance do stick around longer... It is a warm embrace still, Ambre Sultan.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
My Goodness this is another Unapologetically Masculine masterpiece.

If you disliked the aromatic and elegant nature of dior fahrenheit and wanted a more middle eastern,ambery and deeper farenheit that is more seductive, then this is it !

I get deep rich amber,muskyness,violet leaf (gasoline or petrol smell), and a inviting syrupyness without much sweetness at all.

This must have been inspired by the like of encre noire l'extreme.

This is a lady killer and if you like gucci absolute,ecnre nior, fahrenheit and others then this is a niche you have to try !!!

A Amazing amber for the cigar smoking gentleman with a wild side

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: OMG I love this perfume so much it smells like heaven on my skin. I get many compliments when I where it.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: This would be my amber holy grail amongst all that I've tried so far, if only it lasted on me. Somehow I only get an hour or so out of this one, if that. :/ It's beautiful, complex, unique, herbal but not bitter... But the longevity is really letting me down here.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: This was a little too syrupy for my tastes. I like my orientals dry, and this was sticky sweet. I think the amber was just a little too strong, and I like mine to be more in the background. Some of my favorite scents have amber, but not as the leading note. This and Arabie were the only two scents from Serge Lutens I've disliked, and I can't help but wonder if it's because I'm not accustomed to the resinous spice market qualities of a true oriental yet.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
If you want this minus the skank, try Bogart Club 75.
Waaaaaaay cheaper too.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: If you took all the herbs and spices used in Greek and Persian cooking, sizzled them in a pan, caramelized them in tree sap, and added skankiness (after all that has been said and done) to the mix, you would get Ambre Sultan. It is warm, sultry, and powerful. Unfortunately, I cannot see myself wearing this. At least, not yet. Ambre Sultan requires a very confident individual to wear this. Otherwise, it ends up wearing the person.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Utterly swoon-worthy. I've heard of this perfume for years, but only now got around to trying it. It is beautifully smooth, spicy, and resinous, with a deep vanilla amber base. Sexy, substantial, and comforting - I can totally see why it's held as the standard for amber perfumes, and I am dying to get my hands on a full bottle.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I'm delighted to finally try out Serge Lutens Ambre Sultan since it has among the best reputations of the line, most notably as it compares to other amber fragrances in general, and Tom Ford Amber Absolute in particular, and I agree that the comparison is warranted.

It's an amber-dominant fragrance, as the name suggests, with heavy doses of incense and vanilla, and it's in this trinity that it's very similar to the 2015 rendition of Tom Ford Amber Absolute. Ambre Sultan also features the spicy, provocative bay leaf, some woods, and a handful of other minor players (florals, herbs per some note lists) that don't hold a candle to the benzoin-leaning amber dominance.

Given its composition, Ambre Sultan's performance is unsurprisingly very good. It boasts projection that's above average and longevity that's quite strong. At a discounted price (on FragranceNet) of $52 for 50ml, it's surely a bargain.

8 out of 10

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: I haven't written a review since last year, but something about this one...I love rich, intoxicating scents. This gives off the same vibes as Chanel Coromandel and the original Dior Addict. It's smooth, strong, and intoxicating. Fall, winter scent. Feels like a cozy blanket - It surrounds you. Very well blended and longevity is 8+ hours. My first Serge. Will be trying more Serge Lutens now because of this. My skin tends to eat everything, yet this guy lasts and lasts.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: The amber up top is creamy, rich, and round, but it's thrown into orbit by incense that smells a lot like my father using his soldering iron. The contrast is unbelievably wonderful. Love, love, love this!

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
On paper and on skin: The closest I've ever come to a perfect amber. It's warm and spicy without smelling like spices. Heavy throw; it's easy for me to get olfactory fatigue.

Edit: Three months later, I bought a bottle of this beautiful perfume. Interesting, given that early autumn is nearly as warm as summer, and I'd think this was a cool weather perfume. It must be the shortening days and changing leaves.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Oh. OH! This resonates with memories of wearing amber oil while wandering through the adventures of my early 20s, but it is grown up, mature, and so beautifully refined. Suitable for this 40-something woman who doesn't want to smell like a hippie child, but does love the depth and warmth of resins and amber mixed with herbaceous green notes.

It smells of incense and old European churches. Wild days spent under oak trees in the California coastal forests. Riding horseback through the desert. My herb garden in late summer when the fog rolls in but the season's heat still lingers.

These are my memories. Give me more.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
" This fragrance is not an Oriental, but an Arab and a Lutens. That being the case, don't expect it to fit in.

The point of departure was a scented wax, found in a souk and long forgotten in a wooden box. The amber only became sultanesque after I reworked the composition using cistus, an herb that sticks to the fingers like tar, then added an overtone that nobody had ever dreamed of: vanilla. Why? Because vanilla is sticky, too, and it clung to my memory. "

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


There are ambers, and then there is Ambre Sultan.

Ambre Sultan is a big amber perfume with a focus on herbal elements. The point of departure is an overdose of medicinal bay leaf; an uncanny but tremendously successful pairing. There is a touch of oregano; together the herbal parts perfectly complement and cut through the sweetness of amber, resins and vanilla. The herbs are more prominent initially, but prevail till the finish when the vanilla is more prominent. The sweetness is not sticky or cloying, but thick and dry, like a shawl.

Ambre Sultan is immensely enveloping, and retains one's interest unlike ninety five percent of all 'amber' perfumes. One can wear this day in, day out. One can wear this anywhere, from the Sahara to the Poles.

Exceptional.

5/5

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Harsh animalic opening, too daring and almost too strong. Although, magic happens in the first few minutes. This becomes a totally different perfume. So creamy and smooth, resinous and incredibly well blended into a sweet amber. Spicy and oriental largely due to the coriander and myrrh. Just lovely. I totally imagine this as late afternoon scent for the hotter days to sit by the pool drinking a refreshing cocktail. Nevertheless, don't be fooled, this is a super warm perfume: it really shines on colder days.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: As I make my way away from sugary sweet girlie girl scents and into orientals and the like, Ambre Sultan became one of my main wants after going through a sample. I love this resinous and ambery scent! Especially after it has been on my skin for an hour, it becomes magical. The first hour is just as wonderful but when it totally dries down it maintains that resinous sweetness but i can also smell vanilla, myrrh (which I am learning is a note I like) and sandalwood. I imagine that this is what a high end spa would smell like in India.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
(review from a sample)
Ambre Sultan is a gorgeous oriental fragrance. Initially what I smell most are amber and resins, vanilla and bay leaf, plus a bit of spiciness; after a while, on me it is mostly about resins and vanilla - now, my nose is still training, so I can't really distinguish between the various types of resins and spices, but yeah, this is what I and my mom smelled.
It is well rounded, creamy and smooth, without rough edges, and it is pretty long lasting, with moderate sillage.

Surely, the best amber I've smelled so far. It reminds me of the Middle East, unsurprisingly, or better the idea of it since I've never been there!
It is just a tiiiiny bit powdery, that is, I wouldn't wear it in the summer nor warm spring, but it is great for colder seasons.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Good old Serge fragrance. I dislike all his newer creations. But Ambre sultan is from his good days: potent with great sillage and lasting power. Amber, spices and juicy sweetness. Seductive.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I wasn't amazed unfortunately.
Composition is great, it's a quality juice, well blended.

But in my opinion it's really more on a feminime side rather being 50/50 unisex. I dont feel masculine vibe in it. It doesn't say - I am a man. Or - I can be a man.
Sahara Noir has a strong masculine vibe, this one doesn't.

I would recommend everyone to try it, definitely. Buy a decant and let yourself know for educational purposes what this famous fragrance is.
But if you're a man - think twice before getting a full bottle without testing it first.

And in my opinion it's not even closely similar with TF's- Amber Absolute despite some people compare them.
"AA" is fair unisex fragrance to me with different smell.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: 2hrs in, and this turns into an Amber & Angelica show for me. Would much prefer the Bay maintained it's prominence. Still a lovely scent, though.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Oooh .. this one.
It's a tricky perfume that loves to play games on you and acts crazy!

It's a creamy, ambery great for winter perfume. I thought it was Ok at the beginning and said to myself "it's a one time purchase perfume".

I noticed I kept reaching for it. It was the only perfume I reach for. It grow on me. It TRICKED ME!!

The dry down. OMG. Amazing. Powdery. Warm. I kept sniffing myself all the time. And longevity for more than 24hrs.

You like ambery powdery scents? Get it.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: One of the most delicately beautiful amber blend fragrances ever created, and one I have had the privilege of always having a bottle in my collection since it was introduced almost two decades ago, this Serge Lutens unisex classic combines the central amber note with coriander, sandalwood, bay leaf, patchouli, angelica, tolu resin, myrrh, oregano, myrtle, benzoin and vanilla to create a radiant and beautiful juice that has moderate to strong sillage/projection and excellent skin longevity. Perfect for winter and fall days because it is so warm and glowing, this is a beautiful and sweet spicy scent for lovers of amber and Orientals. A true classic that has withstood the test of time and so many imitations. Bravo!

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: This is very good, magical, and it reminds me strongly of Amouage's The Library Collection Opus VI (and also of Bentley's Pour Homme Intense).

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Unlike any other Amber perfume I have tried, this oddly works really well, beautiful and super long-lasting in hot, humid, tropical climate!!! Love love love 5/5.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
This is definitely a loafer of the perfume world, not as exquisite as a pair of heels but much easier to wear.

Perfectly pitched, moderate silage and projection so no fears of it wearing you and everyone with the misfortune of sitting next to you at work out by lunchtime.

As everyone and their dog has mentioned, has a herbal note which doesn't make you want to go and eat Italian so it's all fine. Nice, very wearable amber.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
The juxtaposition of herbal (patchouli, oregano and SL knows what else) and resinous (amber, benzoin, myrrh) actually turns out to be a great 69 position. It all fits like a glove creating a memorable sweet and spicy scent that is both warm and provocative. This amber twists and turns in pleasure but overall feels restrained. Which is a pity because this ride could have been much wilder.
****(*)

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
So it's 37 degrees in Melbourne, dry with a hot wind. This is Amber Sultan weather for me (it strangely smells very dull on my skin in winter). This is EXACTLY the smell of hay-cutting season, and specifically the memory of being a child and walking into the hay-shed and then proceeding to climb up to find a cozy hiding nook in-between the enormous stacks of hay. I find it a very sun-soaked, earthy and joyful scent. Great for an evening walk.

I realise this might be a bit unusual ha!

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Ambre Sultan is my desert island perfume. When all the others are dead and gone, if I'm allowed nothing else, this is the one I'm taking with me. I love all of it, from the dried herbs up top to the warm, vanillic, highly animalic drydown that lasts for hours. Just bought myself a third bottle, this time with the vintage Palais Royal logo, as the original is a bit more skanky than the most recent version. I wear this fragrance at least once a week and it garners more compliments than anything else I own.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Fragrance -Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens
Bottle from - 2015

Amber Sultan opens with a little bit provocative,daring, loud,heavy,animalistic and challenging explosion of spices fused with a little bit sneaking amber and vanilla.
Than as it lingers on the skin potent spices slowly give way to a addictive,smokey,warm,moderatly sweet and resinous mix of amber and vanilla,with a hint of sandalwood.Ambre Sultan is in the middle of the road between a beautiful fragrance and promotion of freedom of artistic expression.It has some similarities to Amber Absolute by Tom Ford,there is no question about it.

Longevity - 9/10(9+ hours)
Silage/Projection - 7,5/10(moderate to high projection and silage for the first 2-3 hours)
Weather - best in autumn and winter
Age - 35+
Compliments - 6/10
Scent - 8/10

Main notes according to me - resins,amber,myrrh,spices,benzoin,vanilla.

The drydown is nice and i get some - sweetness,smokiness,resins,sandalwood,amber and vanilla.

Emotions - unpredictable,dangerous,provocative,addictive,decadence,dark vibe elegance.

Occasion - special occasions and formal events.

Try before you buy.Don't blind buy this one.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: On me it's just a honey-cake with apricot jam.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
If you consider this as a bold or potent scent you should give a try to Ambré Lumière by Molinard who plays the same theme but much louder and with a nice more vanillic dry down.
It's just like if you would compare the same music: one on a good CD player with high quality speakers and the same on an old plate recorded in mono...
In my mind, Ambre Sultan was stronger in the early 2000... Not bad but doesn't Worth its price and reputation anymore...
I wrote this after applying about 20 sprays on my neck & shirt within 3 hours... Opinion confirmed by the 5 colleagues I'm working with today who barely noticed it when they made more comments yesterday about Ambré lumière that filled our space...
And now (14/02/2018) for €120/50ml or €190/75ml, this is ridiculously greedy. Sorry. SL, not anymore.

Lutens reste une référence absolue dans l'univers de la parfumerie de niche, mais je trouve qu'AS a perdu de sa superbe ou faut-il dire de sa radicalité.
Je l'avais porté au début des années 2000, puis mon goût m'avait entraîné vers Bornéo 1834 et Cuir Mauresque.
Cet automne, tout comme l'été, est très "ambré" pour moi. J'achète, je teste, je réexplore...
Ambre Sultan est le chef de file du groupe au sein duquel je trouve à Ambré Lumière plus de charme. Il s'ouvre aussi sur un registre pharmaceutique/aromatique, mais s'étire dans une vanille confortable et charnelle. Ce qui me convient mieux. Et le sillage est bien plus fort.
Un vaporisateur 50 ml que je ne remplacerai pas une fois qu'il sera vide, dans... un certain temps. Parce qu'en bonus, il me file la migraine.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I got this as a blind buy and when I first sprayed it on, my heart sank. Instead of this warm rich, spicy amber I got this disgusting sour piss + booze opening that made it impossible to wear. I couldn't understand the hype around this. Although the dry down a few hours later provided a creamier, more pleasant amber-vanilla, I was quite aghast.

Now it's been a few days and my reaction to that opening hasn't changed, but I will say this: the overall effect is quite charming, but this is not something you can bury your nose in, at least for the first few hours. From about a foot away you get this very warm, delicious boozy vanilla and resinous amber that is dense and foreboding, but enticing. Up close it's sour, pissy, medicinal, pungent.

"Spicy" is a bit misleading as it isn't particularly hot or peppery--its "spiciness" is more in the "spices" bay leaf and coriander, which, strike me as more aromatic rather than anything spicy or warming.

The more I spend time with this, the more I like it, but I have to say it's not for me. Vanilla is not my favorite note in perfume, and contrary to what it says above, I unfortunately, get a lot of it.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Okay so here we go. I really like this fragrance and have really enjoyed it after sampling today but, I already have Ambre 114 and it would seem that the purchase would be redundant. They are very similar and have only a few differences to the trained nose. Not taking away from Ambre Sultan but I wouldn't buy if I already had Ambre 114.

9/10

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
There is something foul that I really don't like in the beginning of Ambre Sultan, something that I feel is unpleasant and makes me a bit nauseated... at the same time, I find Ambre Sultan so very warm and pleasant.

How should I have it? I'm not sure yet. I've gone from "meh, not my cup of tea" to "woow, I LOVE it and I have to order a bottle now, even though I might need to take from my savings account!" to "yikes, what IS this weird rubber-ish smell?".
And I'm kind of still there, I like it at certain moments but I can't get rid of the feeling that it is something unpleasant in the beginning, smelling a bit like... burnt pork? Or burnt skin? I guess I will just make sure my small sample vial gets empty and then I will make up my mind properly. After all, the warm comforting amber and myrrh in Ambre Sultan is really golden and delicious.

Good longevity but one couldn't expect less of a Serge Lutens. I know this is probably one of the most beloved ambers out there and hopefully, I will appreciate it more one day. Just when the burnt-skin note disappears (it might just be a question of skin chemistry). I'm a fan of Lutens otherwise!

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: This one starts off smelling kind of like a medicinal shaving cream which gives it a very masculine opening that I'm not too fond of but that doesn't last long. After about 10 minutes it changes to a nice Amber Sandalwood on my skin which lasts maybe about an hour and then it dries down to a vanilla resin Amber which is sweet and comfy unless at least another five or six hours on my skin. I'm not a fan of the opening on my skin but I love the dry down

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
This may be the best Amber fragrance out there, surely the #1 Lutens fragrance for me.
TF Amber Absolu is great as a dominant amber fragrance. Amber Sultan has a more interesting and pleasing contrasting notes.
You have a great rich and smooth Labdanum amber with a bit of chocolaty Patchouli. Then you have the bracing Green Bay leaf and Angelica, then ad a little spice of oregano and coriander.
It all is so well blended, very nice fragrance just for chilling on a cool Autumn evening.
I put it in my top 5 for Fall and Winter.

Many miss the Myrtle flower here. It's subtle, but adds a beautiful soft herbal floral touch. Making this very enjoyable for woman, along with the soft spices. Very gender neutral.

Rating: 10/10

God bless. John 3:16

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Really not my cup of tea. I can feel salty unpleasant smell. The beginning is horrible. Later it is a bit better but still nothing I would like to wear or smell. It is definitely something different but unfortunately for me not in the right way. I was really curious to try this but I am quite disappointed.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: More faint and subtle than I expected. A pleasing sweet amber, but on me it's too weak, with only a few inches of projection. It's a good cuddle-scent, but not what I'm looking for in terms of all-day powerful enjoyment.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
If the disney film Aladdin was a fragrance it smell like this.

You're about to take a magic carpet ride through a middle eastern spice market. Where all the wonderful aromas seem to come together with your freshly doused amber and myrrh oils. So creamy and warm foreign and exotic and very much handmade quality. Lovely lovely fragrance.

Scent 10:10
Projection 9:10
Longetivity 9:10

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Intoxicating. Makes me feel like I've been transported to an exotic spice market. It's sublime and smooth, not jarring or loud. I adore it. Love it more than Sahara Noir, which had too much smoke for my liking. Takes me to my happy place.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
Gorgeous fragrance! Wonderful quality!

Amber is something I am more inclined to wear during autumn or winter. Still, I do agree it does bloom in the summer.

I think this fragrance does deserve all the accolades it receives here. However, I can't help but to compare it to what is in my view, the Queen of ambers: Ladies' Must de Cartier.

Ambre Sultan is a more straight forward amber, and I find it warmer than Must de Cartier. But to me, Must de Cartier's amber accompanied by its floral accords, green notes and its masterful complexity, make it a composition "sine qua non."

Sorry Ambre Sultan, I really like you, and I'm afraid you may possibly be of better quality than Must de Cartier's current formulation, but you get second place in my heart.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I find many amber scents to be either too starkly linear or inoffensively bland. Fortunately, Ambre Sultan is neither -
rather, it is a masterfully balanced amber scent with enough bite to declare its presence, but also enough warmth to be truly comforting.

Ambre Sultan's composition is simple yet rich. Smooth amber, resin and benzoin notes are lifted by just the right dose of herbal, aromatic bay leaf. It is rounded out by sweet, creamy vanilla and sandalwood. Arm's length projection and good longevity make it eminently wearable. Although sweet, soft and somewhat powdery, Ambre Sultan is definitely unisex. I'm not usually one for orientals or heavier scents, but this is definitely full bottle worthy. Wonderful stuff.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: So wild and elemental. An unchained force of nature. The strong herbal, somewhat medicinal, camphorous, propolis-like opening reminds me to the calamus root (Calami rhizoma) which I sometimes made a horrible tasting tea of, and which smelled like ripe feet. Yet it already shows some dark sweetness, and the amber is just like the smell form the small vial of Indian amber fragrant oil that I bought at an Oriental shop and cherish ever since, it is very close to that at the base phase. I cannot get enough of that wonderful incensy amber scent, it is so much alive, purring, murmuring and humming from my skin, like a furry animal, both soft and lethal but so charming. Smelling this makes me feel one with the elemental forces of nature, like a thunder or a hurricane, or a tiger... so deep, powerful and irresistible, not really in the romantic sense of the word. For me it is highly attractive, but I think for most people it carries an intimidating kind of power. It is definitely beyond words, beyond talking and chasing petty wordly ambitions, it is so much above the power play. I imagine the Red Sea would part again if someone wearing Ambre Sultan would approach it, it carries such an unquestionable force. On the other hand, it is very complex. The dark colour really reflects the nature of this scent, and its texture is thick and oily, leaving a mark on your skin where you applied it.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Danae by Gustav Klimt 1907

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: An idealized walk through bazaars and mosques, this is the fragrance of wood, incense and spices warmed in the summer heat. I tested this fragrance and was at first turned off by the camphorous, almost cough syrupy opening. After lletting it settle though, I became obsessed with the world it created. It's Istanbul in a painting- Topkapi Palace in a bottle. This is a strong, dark, bittersweet perfume and most people would probably designate it for their winter perfume wardrobe. I think this is a smell that goes well with warm weather too- because resins, woods and spices only react so fragrantly in warm weather. What a beautiful, opulent gem of a perfume! Ambre Sultan has swiftly worked its way into the "must always have" section of my collection.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Ambre Sultan is perfectly unisex to me. This amber is spicy, a tad medicinal. At first it reminds me quite a bit of Estee Lauder's Amber Mystique, but whereas that one develops to be dark, smoky, and sweet, Ambre Sultan becomes brighter and not especially sweet, less dense somehow. Actually, it becomes almost savory with the bay and oregano definitely detectable, and while it isn't light, it isn't actually heavy either. It has a bit of a "quintessential" oriental feel to it, and it strikes me as rustic, and so, understated. Chergui strikes me the same way, and that's one thing I love about this house. Their scents are rich and interesting without being over-the-top or stupidly "complex." I am curious to see how Sultan will play out in warmer weather.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
In retrospect Ambre Sultan and LDDM was meant to initiate me into the world of niche fragrances.

I remember that I tested Ambre Sultan in a hot summer day and the experience was initially a shocking one, I felt that my arm will catch fire and I can do nothing to stop it. After that, the dried resins become addictive. Of course, I retested it when the weather became cold and only then I realized the likeness with Mitzah that speak many reviewers, as in cold weather Ambre Sultan become a spiced liqueur.

I think Ambre Sultan was intended to be worn throughout the year, showing its different facets depending on the weather.

Without a doubt, it is one of the best ambers that can be bought and it's sold as a woman perfume, but that makes me smile while I think about other perfumes sold as for men or unisex.

Ambre Sultan, like most Serge Lutens perfumes, is not the most versatile fragrance in the world, in office space should be worn with caution.

I would like to say something about it's price - one of the lowest in the world of niche perfumes, especially regarding at the quality of the ingredients - that shows us once again that enlarging continuously prices of niche perfumes due the cost of ingredients it is a false justification.

Fragrance 10/10
Projection Medium
Longevity 12 h

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew:
I was looking forward to this perfume based on reviews, but ultimately was quite disappointed.

It's a 'nice' amber, but too herby, spicy and savoury for me. I may or may not like it on a man, but it felt too masculine for me to wear out and enjoy. Nothing special when it dried down. I much prefer Laura Mercier's Ambre Passion over this. I sold mine on eBay.

name: Ambre Sultan Serge Lutens (unisex) ~ 2000
reivew: Serge Lutens knows how to do perfume. These aren’t just scents, aromas that dress you up, but composed pieces of artwork. This smells like a desert market 1000 years ago.
